p: While the incidence of human African trypanosomiasis is at a historic low and a new drug, fexinidazole ( Mesu et al., 2018), has recently received positive opinion by the European Medicines Agency, the prospects are slightly gloomy for other protozoal diseases. Chagas’ disease has reached global dimensions (“WHO | Epidemiology” n.d.), and leishmaniasis as well (“Leishmaniasis” n.d.). Sudan has the highest incidence of leishmaniasis in sub-Saharan countries, with 15,000–20,000 new cases per annum ( Hotez and Kamath, 2009). The successful treatment of malaria is threatened by artemisinin-resistant mutants of P. falciparum, first reported from Southeast Asia ( Ariey et al., 2014; Straimer et al., 2015; Ménard et al., 2016) and, more recently, also from Africa ( Lu et al., 2017).
